Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of citizenship judge's decision on residency requirement
Application_Facts: Ms. Kettani applied for Canadian citizenship; claimed 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada within four years prior to application
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship judge approved application; court upheld decision
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Defendant_Behavior: Ms. Kettani provided evidence and testimony regarding her residency
Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation that citizenship judge made unreasonable findings on residency compliance
Assessment_Factor: Credibility of applicant, consistency of evidence, physical presence test
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review process under section 22.1 of the Citizenship Act
Credibility_Assessment: Citizenship judge found Ms. Kettani credible despite inconsistencies
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, supporting documents on travel and residence
Legal_Provision_Cited: Citizenship Act - residency requirement (1,095 days in 4 years)
Application_Basis: Physical presence test applied by citizenship judge
Evidence_Assessed: Travel records, personal testimony, residency declarations
Relief_Sought: Overturn of citizenship judge’s approval of Ms. Kettani’s application
Governing_Rule: Applicant must reside in Canada for at least 1,095 days in the four years preceding application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Alleged inconsistencies in Ms. Kettani's account, but deemed resolved by judge
Outcome: Decision upheld; Ms. Kettani's citizenship application remains approved
Decisional_Body: Citizenship judge, Federal Court (on judicial review)
Harm_Assessment: No harm established; Minister failed to prove unreasonableness
Cause_Description: Minister challenged approval of citizenship based on alleged failure to meet residency requirement
Evidence_Handling: Judge assessed credibility and reconciled inconsistencies in applicant's favor
Evidence_Issues: Inconsistencies in applicant's statements, but not sufficient to undermine credibility
Residency_Compliance: Found to be satisfied based on evidence and credibility
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction under section 22.1 of the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Assessment: Comprehensive evaluation of applicant's evidence by citizenship judge
Decision_Rationale: Decision was reasonable and within acceptable range of outcomes
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship Commission (via citizenship judge), Federal Court
Evidentiary_Issues: Minor inconsistencies addressed and resolved by judge
